headline: Audiio Hires CD Baby Sync Industry Veteran Brett Byrd To Lead TV/Film
summary: Audiio.com, a leading music licensing platform powering millions of creative projects worldwide, today announced the hiring of Brett Byrd as Director of Creative Licensing. A seasoned veteran of the sync licensing industry, Byrd brings over 10 years of experience securing high-profile placements for music in film, television, advertising, and branded content.

headline: Nvidia is again Wall Street's most valuable company. How it got there, by the numbers

Nvidia and other companies benefiting from the boom in artificial intelligence have been a major reason the S&P 500 has recently climbed to a record.  The company’s journey to be one of the world's most prominent companies has produced some eye-popping numbers.

headline: Nvidia Just Became the First Company to Hit a $4 Trillion Market Cap
summary: Nvidia’s record rally just hit another milestone.  The chip maker in Wednesday intraday trading became the first U.S. company in history to hit a $4 trillion valuation, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  The company led by CEO Jensen Huang reached $4.012 trillion shortly after the market opened.

headline: Nvidia Becomes World’s First $4 Trillion Company
summary: A rally in Nvidia's shares lifted its market capitalization above $4 trillion, a world first that caps a remarkable run for the artificial-intelligence chip maker.  Wednesday's milestone comes barely two years after the Santa Clara, Calif.-based company, led by Chief Executive Jensen Huang, notched a $1 trillion closing valuation for the first time.  Nvidia is now worth as much as the 216 smallest companies in the S&P 500 combined, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

raw.headline: Nvidia Becomes World’s First $4 Trillion Company

Wednesday's milestone comes barely two years after the Santa Clara, Calif.-based company, led by Chief Executive Jensen Huang, notched a $1 trillion closing valuation for the first time.  Nvidia is now worth as much as the 216 smallest companies in the S&P 500 combined, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

headline: Nvidia Stock Hit the $4 Trillion Mark. The Mag 7 Is Back.
summary: Nvidia became the first company to cross a $4 trillion market capitalization on Wednesday.  Shares need to close above $163.93 to be the first firm to end a session with a market cap of $4 trillion or more.  Aside from Nvidia, Amazon.com, Microsoft, Meta Platforms, and Alphabet were all up nearly 2% on Wednesday.

headline: Chipmaker Nvidia becomes most valuable company in the world at $4 trillion
summary: Chipmaker Nvidia became the first public company to top $4 trillion in value on Wednesday after two-year investor frenzy.  Nvidia shares rose 2.5%, or $3.97, in early trading Wednesday, topping $164 each.  At the beginning of 2023, Nvidia shares were around $14 each.

headline: Samsung's bet on foldable phones faces major test with slimmer new model
summary: SEOUL (Reuters) -Samsung Electronics on Wednesday unveiled thinner, lighter new foldable phones as it aims to fend off Chinese competition in the higher-margin, premium segment that remains untapped by arch rival Apple.  The South Korean company lost its global smartphone crown to Apple in 2023, and faces growing competition from Chinese rivals like Huawei and Honor.  Meanwhile, Samsung's mainstay chip business has suffered a profit slump stemming in part from its delayed supply of artificial intelligence chips to Nvidia.

raw.headline: Samsung's bet on foldable phones faces major test with slimmer new model
raw.summary: SEOUL (Reuters) -Samsung Electronics on Wednesday unveiled thinner, lighter new foldable phones as it aims to fend off Chinese competition in the higher-margin, premium segment that remains untapped by arch rival Apple.  The South Korean company lost its global smartphone crown to Apple in 2023, and faces growing competition from Chinese rivals like Huawei and Honor.  Meanwhile, Samsung's mainstay chip business has suffered a profit slump stemming in part from its delayed supply of artificial intelligence chips to Nvidia.

headline: AI Weekly: Grok goes rogue, hiring gets hot
summary: STORY: From what happened when Grok went rogue, to a vicious battle for talent in Silicon Valley, this is AI Weekly.Grok is in trouble again.Elon Musk’s xAI had to remove posts by its chatbot, after complaints that they contained antisemitic content and praise for Adolf Hitler.xAI moved to delete the posts, and said it could quickly update the AI model where there was evidence it had been badly trained.A court also blocked some Grok content in Turkey, after authorities said the bot had made insulting remarks about country President Tayyip Erdogan.The war for talent is getting hot in Silicon Valley, and it’s Meta fanning the flames.Ilya Sutskever is having to take over as boss of his startup Safe Superintelligence, after losing chief executive Daniel Gross to the Facebook parent firm.Bloomberg News says Apple has also lost its top AI models exec to Mark Zuckerberg’s company.Meta has been hiring aggressively in a bid to match OpenAI and other rivals.A bot sowed confusion for diplomats, when someone used an AI-generated voice to impersonate U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio.The person reportedly contacted three foreign ministers and two U.S. officials, sometimes leaving voice notes.Their intent was to gain access to information or accounts, according to a diplomatic cable seen by Reuters.The EU isn’t backing down on its new AI rules.Brussels has dismissed appeals by Meta, Alphabet and other big names to delay the regulations for years.Now the European Commission says there is no option to “stop the clock” on the rules, which aim to set guardrails for AI.But it says it will takes steps to simplify the measures, including for small firms.And Microsoft is cutting jobs to help pay for bots.Some 4% of roles face the chop at the Windows maker, as it tries to find savings amid massive investment in AI.It’s pledged about $80 billion in capital spending this year, taking a bite out of profit margins.

raw.headline: AI Weekly: Grok goes rogue, hiring gets hot
raw.summary: STORY: From what happened when Grok went rogue, to a vicious battle for talent in Silicon Valley, this is AI Weekly.Grok is in trouble again.Elon Musk’s xAI had to remove posts by its chatbot, after complaints that they contained antisemitic content and praise for Adolf Hitler.xAI moved to delete the posts, and said it could quickly update the AI model where there was evidence it had been badly trained.A court also blocked some Grok content in Turkey, after authorities said the bot had made insulting remarks about country President Tayyip Erdogan.The war for talent is getting hot in Silicon Valley, and it’s Meta fanning the flames.Ilya Sutskever is having to take over as boss of his startup Safe Superintelligence, after losing chief executive Daniel Gross to the Facebook parent firm.Bloomberg News says Apple has also lost its top AI models exec to Mark Zuckerberg’s company.Meta has been hiring aggressively in a bid to match OpenAI and other rivals.A bot sowed confusion for diplomats, when someone used an AI-generated voice to impersonate U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio.The person reportedly contacted three foreign ministers and two U.S. officials, sometimes leaving voice notes.Their intent was to gain access to information or accounts, according to a diplomatic cable seen by Reuters.The EU isn’t backing down on its new AI rules.Brussels has dismissed appeals by Meta, Alphabet and other big names to delay the regulations for years.Now the European Commission says there is no option to “stop the clock” on the rules, which aim to set guardrails for AI.But it says it will takes steps to simplify the measures, including for small firms.And Microsoft is cutting jobs to help pay for bots.Some 4% of roles face the chop at the Windows maker, as it tries to find savings amid massive investment in AI.It’s pledged about $80 billion in capital spending this year, taking a bite out of profit margins.

summary: Apple’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) racing drama “F1 the Movie” roared into theaters, generating an impressive $144 million in global revenue, which included $55.6 million in North America, making it the tech company's biggest opening ever for an original film. headline: Apple Has Dropped the Ball on AI. Buying Perplexity Could Help It Catch Up, Say Analysts.
summary: Apple  is fresh out of luck.  The iPhone maker must act fast to capitalize on artificial intelligence before it’s too late—an acquisition could be the answer.  While hyperscalers like  Alphabet Amazon.com  and  Meta Platforms  have seized the opportunity to monetize AI, which the firm dubs “the biggest tech trend in the last 50 years,”  Apple  remains sidelined, “watching this 4th Industrial Revolution race go by at 100 miles an hour.”

headline: Apple eyes US Formula 1 broadcast rights after 'F1: The Movie' success, FT reports
summary: The report follows the strong box office performance of Apple's high-octane racing film "F1: The Movie", which has grossed $293 million in its first 10 days, according to Variety and other outlets.  The iPhone maker is challenging current U.S. broadcaster ESPN, owned by Disney, for the Formula 1 rights next year, the FT report said, citing sources familiar with the matter.  Netflix's "Formula 1: Drive to Survive" series helped boost the sport's popularity in the United States, a momentum Apple now hopes to capitalize on.

Netflix's "Formula 1: Drive to Survive" series helped boost the sport's popularity in the United States, a momentum Apple now hopes to capitalize on.

headline: Could Apple Soon Lose Its Top Position in Warren Buffett's Portfolio?
summary: Apple has been one of Warren Buffett's largest holdings for years, but the distance between second spot has been shrinking.  Buffett has been unloading Apple stock and it has also been falling in value.  Warren Buffett has famously referred to iPhone maker Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) as "probably the best business I know in the world."

headline: Apple COO Jeff Williams to Step Down; Design Team Will Report to CEO Tim Cook
summary: Apple’s chief operating officer plans to hand the role off this month and retire later this year after roughly a decade as the tech giant’s No. 2 under Chief Executive Tim Cook.
